title: Coal21 chief flag CCS project within 12 months
text:
The head of Coal21 Mark McCallum told The Australian Financial Review National Energy Summit he hopes to invest $200 million on a carbon capture and storage (CCS) plant in Queensland within the next 12 months.

Mr McCallum, who is also the general manager of climate and energy at the Minerals Council of Australia, believes there is huge opportunity for CCS in Australia and said numerous US black coal power stations were already utilising the technology and producing power at around $70 a megawatt hour.

CCS is too bloody expensive said Grattan's Tony Wood Christopher Pearce

He said the Petra Nova project south of Houston – a joint venture between NRG Energy and JX Nippon that is the world’s largest operating post-combustion carbon dioxide capture system – is a particular standout.

But the Grattan Institute’s energy program Director, Tony Wood, said CCS was “too bloody expensive for Australia”.

“It comes in one size – and that’s big.”
description: Experts say carbon capture and storage to play a vital role in global energy future, despite concerns about the cost of the technology.
